chapterTitle: Introduction to Valuation:The Time Value of Money

columns.text:
### Requirement 1 ###

We are asked what do present value of an investment means.
The present value of an investment is the sum of its future cash flows discounted at the appropriate discount rate.

### Requirement 2 ###

We are asked what is the opposite of the process of discounting a future amount back to the present.
Discounting a future amount is the opposite of compounding, which accrues interest on investment over time for a greater return.

### Requirement 3 ###

We are asked what is discounted cash flow valuation.
The practice of determining the value of a future cash flow by discounting it from its present value is known as discounted cash flow valuation (DCF).

### Requirement 4 ###

We are asked what is the present value of $1 to be received in t periods assuming a discount rate of r per period.

The present value of $1 to be received in t periods assuming a discount rate of r per period is:

$$
\begin{align*}
\text{PV} &= \$1 \times \dfrac{1}{(1+r)^t}\\\
&= \dfrac{1}{(1+r)^t}\\\
\end{align*}
$$

wherein,
$\dfrac{1}{(1+r)^t}$  is the present value factor for $1 at $r$ percent for $t$ periods.

In this exercise, we must define the present value when investing and analyze the given statement. In addition, we will explain the valuation of discounted cash flows and determine the present value using the given information.

a) **The present value** is the worth of cash that will be received in the future via one or more payments, discounted at the market interest rate. It is always less expensive to get cash now than to receive the same amount of future cash flows later on, since cash received now may be invested immediately, generating a larger return than a promise to receive cash in the future. In order to compute the present value of a financial asset, it is required to first determine the interest rate that will be utilized for discounting purposes. The market rate of interest is the most theoretically correct rate of interest; nevertheless, the rate of interest may be adjusted upward or downward to account for perceived risk associated with the underlying cash flows. For example, if the cash flows are regarded to be very problematic, a higher discount rate may be warranted, resulting in a lower current value.

b) The process of **discounting** a future amount back to the present is the opposite of **compounding**. In the process of discounting the future amount, the present-day value of the future amount is determined. Identifying and comprehending the notion of discounting future values in order to calculate current worth is critical to understanding the time value of money.

c) **Discounted cash flow** (DCF) is a valuation approach that determines the value of an investment based on future cash flows. DCF may be used to estimate the current value of an investment based on its expected future return. This method forecasts a sequence of future cash flows or profits, after which it discounts them to account for the time value of money. The temporal value of money is discounted from a series of projected future cash flows or profits. To put it another way, one dollar now is worth more than one dollar in the future because that dollar may be put to work for you in the form of investments in the future. In order to assess whether or not an investment's future cash flows are worthwhile, discounted cash flow applies a discount rate.

d) Formula for calculating the present value is shown below in the following way:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PV}=\dfrac{\text{FV}_{\text{t}}}{(1+\text{r})^{\text{t}}}
\end{align*}$$

Where:

PV = Present Value

FV$_{\text{t}}$ = Future Value

r = Interest Rate

t = Number of Periods

According to the provided information, we can see that the future value (FV$_{\text{t}}$) is $1, so we will substitute the given value into equation from step 5 as follows:

$$
\text{PV}=\dfrac{1}{(1+\text{r})^{\text{t}}}
$$
